articles.headline: Road to New Confidence at BP Runs Through U.S.
articles.snippet: The expected choice of Robert Dudley as BP’s next chief executive shows a recognition that the spill will be a top concern for some time.
articles.abstract: The expected choice of Robert Dudley as BP’s next chief executive shows a recognition that the spill will be a top concern for some time.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON  Robert Dudley, whose appointment as chief executive of BP was announced Tuesday, faces a long road to restore confidence in the embattled company  particularly in the United States, the biggest part of BP’s business.
articles.byline: By Julia Werdigier and Jad Mouawad

articles.headline: Pressured, Nike to Help Workers in Honduras
articles.snippet: Student groups had pressed Nike to pay severance that the two subcontractors in Honduras had failed to pay.
articles.abstract: Student groups had pressed Nike to pay severance that the two subcontractors in Honduras had failed to pay.
articles.lead_paragraph: Facing pressure from universities and student groups, the apparel maker Nike announced on Monday that it would pay $1.54 million to help 1,800 workers in Honduras who lost their jobs when two subcontractors closed their factories.

articles.headline: Leaks Add to Pressure on White House Over Strategy
articles.snippet: Political reaction to the disclosure of classified documents increased the pressure on President Obama to defend his war strategy as a war-financing bill looms.
articles.abstract: Political reaction to the disclosure of classified documents increased the pressure on President Obama to defend his war strategy as a war-financing bill looms.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The White House sought to reassert control over the public debate on the Afghanistan war on Monday as political reaction to the disclosure of a six-year archive of classified military documents increased pressure on President Obama to defend his war strategy.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: Panel Seen Approving F-35 Engine, Risking Veto
articles.snippet: Despite increasing calls for deficit reduction, one program opposed by the White House — an alternate engine for the joint strike fighter — so far refuses to die.
articles.abstract: Despite increasing calls for deficit reduction, one program opposed by the White House — an alternate engine for the joint strike fighter — so far refuses to die.
articles.lead_paragraph: Despite increasing calls from lawmakers for deficit reduction, one military program opposed by the White House and Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates  an alternate engine for the joint strike fighter  so far refuses to die.

articles.headline: Retailers Pay More to Get Cargo (No Guarantee)
articles.snippet: As retailers cut inventory, the shipping industry scaled back, leading to higher prices and regular delays.
articles.abstract: As retailers cut inventory, the shipping industry scaled back, leading to higher prices and regular delays.
articles.lead_paragraph: The grills shaped like kegs and toolboxes, ordered for a Father’s Day promotion at Cost Plus World Market, arrived too late for the holiday. At the Container Store, platinum-color hangers, advertised in a summer sale catalog, were delivered days after the sale began. At True Value Hardware, the latecomers were fans and portable chairs.

articles.headline: With New Stars, Reality Shows See Costs Rise
articles.snippet: The stars of “Jersey Shore” as a group earned about $25,000 for the first season. Now they will reportedly earn at least that much for each episode.
articles.abstract: The stars of “Jersey Shore” as a group earned about $25,000 for the first season. Now they will reportedly earn at least that much for each episode.
articles.lead_paragraph: Snooki had kissed The Situation, Ronnie had hugged Sammi goodbye and the cameras had stopped rolling. Last summer, “Jersey Shore” wasn’t yet a runaway hit; it was just another reality show in the works for MTV. Nonetheless, the show’s executive producer, SallyAnn Salsano, sat the young cast members down and gave them each a gift  and a warning.

articles.headline: Iraqi Militants Stealing Blood for the Injured
articles.snippet: Guards at medical facilities have often stood by as the robberies take place, according to workers.
articles.abstract: Guards at medical facilities have often stood by as the robberies take place, according to workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSUL, Iraq  Members of Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia have been holding up blood banks and hospitals at gunpoint, stealing blood for their wounded fighters rather than risk having them arrested at medical facilities, according to Iraqi doctors, employees at health centers and the Sunni insurgents themselves.
articles.byline: By Timothy Williams and Yasmine Mousa

articles.headline: Some Backup for Goldman on A.I.G.
articles.snippet: Documents released by the Senate Finance Committee show Goldman Sachs had hedged against losses to A.I.G. and that the Fed was aware of it.
articles.abstract: Documents released by the Senate Finance Committee show Goldman Sachs had hedged against losses to A.I.G. and that the Fed was aware of it.
articles.lead_paragraph: For almost two years, Goldman Sachs has been spinning what many believed was a far-fetched tale.
